properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Big Cord, Mirranatwa, Strachans, Victoria Valley
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Big Cord, Mirranatwa, Strachans, Victoria Valley.
  • The a bushfire that started at Grampians National Park - Victoria Range (Bullawin) is not yet under control. 
  • This Advice message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 11.04 yesterday.
  • The spread of the bushfire has stopped, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
  • Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees, clear tracks.
  • Smoke may be visible in the area.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions.   
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway is closed between Horsham & Cavendish. Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures. 
  • Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 07/02/2025 12:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Smoke:

  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. 
  • If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: 18Km Ne Cavendish
Issue Date: Thursday 06 February 2025, 09:17 am
Next Update: Friday 07 February 2025, 12:20 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36508/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Big Cord, Mirranatwa, Strachans, Victoria Valley.
- The a bushfire that started at Grampians National Park - Victoria Range (Bullawin) is not yet under control. 
- This Advice message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 11.04 yesterday.
- The spread of the bushfire has stopped, but the situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
- Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees, clear tracks.
- Smoke may be visible in the area.


There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.action: Monitor Conditions As They Are Changing
properties.location: Cherrypool, Glenisla, Glenisla Crossing, Brimpaen, Rocklands
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for parts South East of Brimpaen, Cherrypool, Glenisla, Glenisla Crossing, Rocklands.
  • This Watch and Act replaces the Watch and Act issued on 6 February at 11.30 am.
  • There is a bushfire in the Grampians National Park that is not yet under control. 
  • There is active bushfire in the area. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act. 
  • While the immediate spread of fire has been halted there is still active fire within the current fire footprint. 
  •  Crews will continue to consolidate containment lines, patrol and monitor hotspots.
  • Smoke will be visible in the area. 
The situation can change at any time. You must monitor conditions and be ready to act.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor changes to the situation. Increased wind speed, change in wind direction, smoke or poor visibility can indicate the situation is changing. 
  • Enact your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • If you have time, check your neighbours to see if they are monitoring conditions. 
  • Protect yourself and your family.
Leave if the situation changes or you feel unsafe. 
Remember to:
  • Take your pets, medications, mobile phone and charger. 
  • Many people have died trying to leave at the last minute during fires. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends that are away from the warning area.
Impacts in your area:
  • Firesfighters are responding to this fire.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Grampians National Park
Parts of the Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park are open to visitors. For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap.  

Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 07/02/2025 09:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires) 
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • For information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Berringa, Piggoreet, Staffordshire Reef, Dereel, Enfield
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Berringa, Dereel, Enfield, Piggoreet, Staffordshire Reef.
  • The bushfire in the vicinity of Dales Rd and Donald McLeans Rd, Springdallah is under control.
  • Fire crews have managed to contain this fire.
  • Crews will remain on scene for several hours continuing to strengthen containment lines. 
  • Smoke may still be visible in the area.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice message issued at 3.50pm today.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
This will be the final message on this fire.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
  • Bulldozers are operating in the area.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

The next update is expected by 07/02/2025 06:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

  • There is a bushfire at Grampians National Park - Victoria Range (Bullawin) that is not yet under control.

  • There is active fire within the Victoria Valley area in Grampians National Park.
  • Fire crews continue to work on building containment lines to suppress fire activity.
  • Smoke may be visible in the area.
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area:

Grampians National Park
For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap.  

Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 07/02/2025 02:30 pm or as the situation changes.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Kaniva, Lillimur, Lillimur South, Miram, Miram South, the southern part of Serviceton, Yanipy.
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Kaniva, Lillimur, Lillimur South, Miram, Miram South, the southern part of Serviceton, Yanipy.
  • This advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 9:52pm 5 February. 
  • This message applies to two bushfires in the Little Desert National Park that are not yet under control. 
  • There is a bushfire in the Central Block of the Little Desert National Park that is an extension of the main fire in a northerly direction towards Miriam South and Kaniva. Firefighters have slowed the spread of the fire for now, but the situation can change at any time. 
  • There is separate a fire in the Western Block of the Little Desert National Park, near Lillimur South. This fire is no longer spreading. 
  • Fire Crews continue to treat hazardous trees, monitor hotspots and consolidate containment lines. 
  • Smoke may be visible in the area.
  • There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Kaniva-Edenhope Road between Western Hwy and Natimuk-Frances Rd is closed.
  • There may be other local road closures. 
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
Smoke
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 07/02/2025 11:30 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Little Desert National Park - Sand Track
Issue Date: Thursday 06 February 2025, 12:20 pm
Next Update: Friday 07 February 2025, 11:30 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36516/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Kaniva, Lillimur, Lillimur South, Miram, Miram South, the southern part of Serviceton, Yanipy.
- This advice message replaces the Advice message issued at 9:52pm 5 February. 
- This message applies to two bushfires in the Little Desert National Park that are not yet under control. 
- There is a bushfire in the Central Block of the Little Desert National Park that is an extension of the main fire in a northerly direction towards Miriam South and Kaniva. Firefighters have slowed the spread of the fire for now, but the situation can change at any time. 
- There is separate a fire in the Western Block of the Little Desert National Park, near Lillimur South. This fire is no longer spreading. 
- Fire Crews continue to treat hazardous trees, monitor hotspots and consolidate containment lines. 
- Smoke may be visible in the area.



- There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes.

properties.location: Little Desert National Park - Sand Track

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Goroke, Minimay, Morea, the western part of Nurcoung, Peronne.
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Goroke, Minimay, Morea, the western part of Nurcoung, Peronne..
  • This Advice message replaces the advice message issued at 12.19 5 February. 
  • This message applies to the bushfire in the Central Block of the Little desert National Park.
  • There is currently increased fire activity in the central block north of McDonald Track. 
  •  Fire is running through unburnt fuels in an easterly direction back towards area that has been previously burnt. 
  •  Fire crews are responding to this fire with heavy equipment. 
  •  Increased smoke will be visible for several hours.
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings.  
  •  Review your fire survival plan.  
  •  If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Kaniva-Edenhope Road between Western Hwy and Natimuk-Frances Rd is closed. 
  •  Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.Bushfires can spread quickly and are extremely dangerous. 
  •  Emergency services will remain in the area.
Smoke
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 07/02/2025 10:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Bornes Hill, Borough Huts, Flat Rock Crossing, Jimmy Creek, Mafeking, Dunkeld, Glenthompson, Moyston, Pomonal
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Bornes Hill, Borough Huts, Dunkeld, Flat Rock Crossing, Glenthompson, Jimmy Creek, Mafeking, Moyston, Pomonal
  • The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill is now Under Control.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 3.00pm on Tuesday 4 February 2025.
  • Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to monitor hotspots, treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
  • There is active fire within the Victoria Valley area in Grampians National Park.
  • Fire crews continue to work on building containment lines to suppress fire activity.
  • Smoke may be visible in the area
There is currently no threat to you, but you should stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. 
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Drive with caution. Obey road closure signs.  
  • Visitors are reminded to be cautious of ongoing risks and changes to the environment which may include fallen or damaged trees, smoke and injured wildlife.
  • If you see impacted wildlife - call 1300 356 682. 
Recovery and resilience
If you have been or may be impacted by bushfire, it is understandable if you are feeling concerned and experiencing a mix of strong mental, emotional or physical reactions right now. For emergency relief information during major incidents, call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226 or visit www.emergency.vic.gov.au/relief
Impacts in your area: 
  • Drivers may encounter fire crews and heavy machinery on roads and tracks. Please take care and drive safely. 
  • Many roads within the fire affected area remain closed. Check the VicTaffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures.

Smoke
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000). 

Grampians National Park
  • The Southern Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park is closed due to the current weather conditions, which are causing unpredictable fire activity.
  • This includes Mt Abrupt, Mt Sturgeon and Piccaninny walking tracks.
  • The Grampians Tourist Road from Dunkeld to Halls Gap is currently open.
  • For details on access to the park, visit the Parks Vic website or call in to Brambuk - The National Park and Cultural Centre in Halls Gap.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/02/2025 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
